div.p: This is a set of rules, which represent the aspects typically encountered in a SciFi generic setting akin to Star Trek, Dark Matter, or Firefly. It is not intended for very realistic setting such as Expanse nor for Space Fantasy like Star Wars. Also see Main Rule for the generic details.

Many values are taken from Harnmaster (various versions) and fan publication such as Gunmaster from Bill Gant (various versions) but adapted to the setting. The intention was to benefit from predetermined, balanced values. For example, when comparing firearms with melee weapons, balanced effects are possibly play-tested.

Skill testing is a micro-negotiation. The GM describes the task and the dimensions available. The character in question names the skills he thinks are most appropriate. The GM then names the diffculty for each of the skills and how they can potentially be combined.

Then n5 is rolled, adding skill value (SV). The task difficulty value is subtracted from the roll and if the net result is non-negative, the skill has been successfully employed; if the roll is negative, the attempt has failed.

For example, if a PC declares the intent to perform a gymnastic feat, he would suggest to the GM that “I have the Acrobatics skill”. The GM would then tell the player “this has a difficulty of 15.” In cases where success or failure may not be obvious, the GM should make the roll secretly and record the relevant skill of the PCs beforehand.
To determine the degree of success or failure, use the dimensions.

When two characters use skills against each other, each character makes a p5 skill roll appropriate to the skill in question and the results are compared to give a net result. The character with the higher result wins the challenge. If both characters achieve the same success level, this is a stalemate. If a tie is not appropriate to the situation, toss a coin.
The star-scale is often used to simplify evaluation.
A convenience table for the 5-addition of zeroes. Rounding is to one fractional digit only. Multiples of 2 are left out; every doubling means a +5.

The following shows example dimensions. Finding the appropriate dimension depends on the concrete circumstances. Consider what would be appropriate for an untrained individual (SV 0) and what is expected (the average result) for a sufficiently educated person (SV 20). Interpret the results inbetween and outside of the bounds accordingly.
Judging the values of goods produced or performances delivered. Also see the Main Rule

Climbing Speed is 1/4 walking speed at success. Speed can be increased by 1/4 for a -10 penalty, or decreased accordingly, but negative speeds are not allowed. E.g. for a +10, one can opt to simply try and cling to a holding to not fall down. A failure results in a fall, usually evenly distributed among the total climb.

One dimension is the time, which it takes to achieve the wound level zero on the defender. The wound level is a separate dimension; you can use trajectories. Once a (rolled) progression has reached its goal, a new skill roll is made. It is therefore possible to play 4-second round-based combat. The weapon table show the base time it takes to attack once. This is multiplied by the number in the table.

The wounds are the result of the value calculation divided by 5, e.g. a 35 value result is 7 wounds. Wounds only apply, if the attack/defense + n5 result is positive. Negative wounds may result from cover and other circumstances but are not applied.
The fractional parts for the higher values in the time dimension mean that multiple attacks “connect” at the same time. This is to avoid combat in split seconds.
Weapons list the minimal recovery time, i.e. reload time.
For grappling, wounds are treated as penalty to any physical activity that instead of damage to heal. Such wounds are immediately reduced to zero, once the grapple is no longer maintained.
Healing time is given for one wound point. Note that a reduction in the effective wound points causes re-evaluation of the effective healing rate, but should be ignored for playability.

Wounds are the (individual) task levels, but the wounds themselves adversely affect healing individually and the time unit is days. Add half the skill value of a medic present when determining the healing rate. Healing rate can be improved with during the healing process in the same manner.

Initiative reflects battle experience, discipline, and morale. Initiative determines the speed in which characters can assess a stressful situation. Characters take the time listed before they can act. An ambush gives a penalty. During the time a character is “frozen” this way, he is trying to understand the situation he is in and assesses the options he has. He is cautious during that time. General awareness issues are not covered by Initiative. Battle-hardened characters may come into the fractional range. Fractions can be used to determine who goes first.
The situation in combat changes constantly. One action is assumed to take 4 seconds, going prematurely incurs the usual 5-subtraction penalty. (Acting every 8 seconds can occasionally lend a bonus.)

For round-based combat, Initiative usually simply determines the order of activity. Changing the order or acting twice by accepting penalties should be avoided, as it can quickly lead to escalation, the avoidance of which is precisely the reason round-based combat is used.
This dimension can also be used as knowledge about knowledge, i.e. how sure is the character that his reproduction of the knowledge is correct.
-10: Knowing that the domain can provide knowledge is shaky.
0: Character knows the domain for such knowledge exists and can separate it from different domains.
10: The basic concepts are known, advanced concepts have been heard of but cannot be applied.
20: Most concepts of the domain are known and can be applied. The character is less confident with fringe concepts.
30: The domain is understood with ease. Improvement of the art is possible.
40: Mastery of the domain as far as humanly possible. Improvement of the art is a normal task.
Consider load and acceleration for unusually fast movers (or abusers).

This is used to determine how quick short reactive actions are made. Those are actions that need to be completed within a few seconds, usually in combat. If an action extends beyond 100% duration when attempting to be quick, it fails.

Yield is used for various creation or harvesting tasks. Yield can usually be compensated by spending more time but in some cases a minimum result must be achieved or time cannot be consecutively be spent, “ruining” the result.
As example: 2 time units with with SV 5 yields 3.

Skills can be specialized. Specialization has the advantage of reducing the task level in a specific domain, which general skill would not do. For example specializing in a specific melee weapon such as a sword, would reduce the task of fighting against an opponent more susceptible to such attacks compared to general melee weapons.
For a task multiple skills may be applicable. Usually they can be 5-added but the difficulty may also be different for their application.

At the beginning of each combat the players and GM should jointly decide which action options they want to allow and which will simply be abstracted by a set penalty/bonus by the GM. This can speed up combat tremendously. If tactical options outside of combat are affected by the decision, the GM should inform the players of that. For instance, if vehicle combat is too tedious today, than the PCs might just as well disembark already to allow for smoother combat resolution.

In order to simulate larger combats with many participants, the usual 5-Addition can be used. It does not provide as many tactical options as individual combat does, but greatly reduces time spent. Both time and wound dimension should be scaled linearly with the number of particpipants. E.g. a wound of 5 after 30 seconds would scale to a total of 50 points after 5 minutes for 10 people or to 500 points after 50 minutes for 100 people. The points should be distributed in reasonable batches on the participants on each side, the smallest batch size being the wounds rolled. People can be hit multiple times.

For every reduction of the target zone by 50% (exponentially) shoot at -5. A miss by 5 points randomly assigned to the five equally sized surrounding fields of the aim plane. Note that this gives a 20% chance of hitting the other 50% of the target zone. This can be applied repeatedly to either understand how wildly off a shot was or when firing at a wall of enemies.
For the purpose of attitude to an attacker, normal humans are considered a “block” of 100% by 50% by 25%.

Skills to evade do not include any mental skills or missile skills. Unarmed, melee weapons, strength are all applicable. If the same skill is used for multiple, simultaneous actions, it is at +5, compensating some of the penalty for multiple actions.

Any combination of Dodging, Blocking, and Parrying an attack is a single action and called Evade. Evade is not assumed at the same time an attack is contemplated by the defender himself. Evade is a 4 second Combat activity. Calculate separate, synchronous applications accordingly, i.e. a second defense causes a -5 penalty to both parries, a third causes a -7.9 to all and so on. The same is true for combining attacks and defenses at the same time.

Evade is at a penalty of Initiative divided by the travel time of a missile. Example: An arrow shot at a distance of 100m travels one second. If the Initiative is 1s, that is a -1 to Evade, an Initiative of 5s has a -5. A bullet flying at 600m/s puts Evade at -6 and -30 respectively. This penalty cannot reduce Evade to less than 0.

Damage taken increases with every complete multiple of 5 injury level above 10 every 4s. For example, a 16-20 point injury causes 2 points per 4 seconds, or 1 point of bloodloss every 1 second. This number is lost until treatment is applied. Treat the final sum as a separate injury. Some wounds will not cause bloodloss (e.g. Frost) including wounds to inanimate objects.
Sleep: Every 24 hours without sleep take 5 wounds, which cummulate into a single wound. Observe Incapacitating and Destroyed. These heal at 1 per hour of sleep.
Air Every minute without air take 5 wounds, which cummulate into a single wound. Observe Incapacitating and Destroyed. These heal at 1 per second of fresh air.

Every character has an Engagement Zone of 1.5m radius about his center (that does not extend into blocked areas). The Engagement Zone of a conscious, prone character is only half that. Unconscious characters have no Engagement Zones but may constitute obstacles. A character may be (melee) attacked upon entering an enemy’s Engagement Zone until he leaves that zone. This entering or leaving may be active or passive. It is possible to be engaged with an arbitrary number of enemies at a time.
Use Unarmed skill when no weapon is involved. Multiple grapples are allowed , but keep track of the grappled weapons of all opponents, they can no longer be used to full potential.
Use Fine motor skill.

Hitting the wrong target can happen in melee combat. Anybody within an engagement zone is subject to an (unintentional) attack with SV 0. This can be added to the benefit of other attackers as per multiple attacks above or resolved individually with the goal of 0 damage. A character who is attacking (or being attacked by) a prone enemy increases Attack/Defense SV with that character by 5.

Count everything within 30 degrees firing arc as a single target with task level 0. To simplify calculations, weapons list range categories to hit single humans sized targets and Evade is allowed for them. However, firing into a group uses Aiming and 5-addition. This increase can be used purposefully and can be quite devastating when firing at advancing troops. On the other hand, a miss is calculated before the damage calculation applies and even a group hit allows the individual hit to use Evade - but against the “spread” roll. It also follows that for a single target, at double the listed weapon range, the attacker receives a -5.

Subtract attacker vs defender speed in m/s, when attacking during a move (or the second before and after). For missile attacks use speed perpendicular to the direction of the attack. If attacking during a move subtract a percentage of 20 correspording to the percentage of a maximal move during the period. The same is valid for Evade during a Move.

A 4 second round can be spent to prepare an activity, which shall happen at a dedicated instance. The conditions must be evaluated in less than a second. Use Initiative at +20 or alternativly the activity at +5. Active conditions such as suppressive fire are notwithstanding.

The push attempt must be in the direction the attacker is facing and the attacker must follow. The defender has a choice to evade into a semi-circle of up to 120 degrees, assuming no obstacles. Instead of Injury points, meters (pushed) are used. The defender is forced to deduct the move from his action allowance, regardless of whether he resists or not. A resist deducts from the distance forced and can even be used as a counter-push. The pushed character may opt to fall prone instead at any time, for instance to avoid falling of a cliff. Any remaining distance is forfeit.
Use Gross motor skill for any of these situations. The result of the latter two is a stumble or a fumble, while the first is the Combat dimension time it takes to escape the prone condition.

Any new wound of at least 1 point results in a Shock chance. Use accumulated injury and fatigue as difficulty for a roll against 20. Failure is measured in the Yield Dimension as minutes. Multiple Shock rolls per round can be 5-added.

Combatants who sustain Serious or Grievous wounds may die during the healing routine. On the other hand, various types of medicine or prosthetics can improve healing greatly. For descriptive purposes, wounds are called Minor, Serious, Grievous, Incapacitating, and Destroyed in steps of 5.
Incapacitating:. The system affected cannot be used but still be healed.
Destroyed: The system affected lost its integrity and cannot be healed. For living beings this means instant death.
The following table contains examples for the for formulas given here and signal the readily available variants.

Skill: A short weapon is any weapon smaller than 50cm x 20cm x 10cm in every direction. A weapon smaller than 1/4 of that in every direction can be used as Unarmed. Any object used as weapon but not built for the purpose will give penalties, typically -5.

Weight/BEP: A melee weapon will have 8 BEP for a weight of 2.5 kg. Every decrease of 1 BEP leads to half of the original weight, the corresponding is true for increases. Remember that a weapon stills to be controlled during combat. This is uncommon for weapons beyond 2kg, as the skill is usually not trained on those extreme weapons. Weapons that are easier to manufacture generally (or are dual purposed, e.g. can also be thrown) deal less damage.

Guns Remember that only 1 or two handed weapons are allowed. The units used are found in the table. BEP shall equal nozzle velocity times Amunition weight, while BEP times the number of hands used shall equal 8 times the gun weight. Range shall always be 20m for (single) hand guns and 40m for rifles. Ammunition weight shall be 10 times the difference of the firing rate and the number of free hands (0 or 1).

The weight of one clip case is included in the weapon weight. Energy weapons scale arbitrarily, while guns use only whole numbers, i.e. individual projectiles. Also note that armor and BEP are applied after skill damage (and only if the net skill application is positive).
Restricted energy weapons can be used with other, appropriate skills. Unlisted artillerie generally does not distinguish between energy or projectile.

Explosives such as grenades lose 1 point of damge per meter squared away from ground zero, e.g. a BEP 50 grenade is effectively harmless at 7m distance. Skill cannot increase damage, only precision. Energy weapons may be used with an explosive cone, assuming a ¼m2 ground zero at aim distance. For example, firing at 4m2 gives -16 BEP. Using eccentric cones requires configuration time.
